text: Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting. Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we talked about an MRI which would tell us more about your back to see if there's something in the middle of the bone that would be cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could look at a PET scan, which you know, PSA is over point seven. These PET scans can be pretty good about picking up things. And basically they're just looking at how tumors are growing and if they’re growing, then they light up. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that we can do one of those scans and see how much lights up. Usually what…I don't like these tests because they tend to find what's under the radar. Because we know there's disease- Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study-

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
